isis.stitle: TSI 05-13-03 - Allison WT Transmission Control Module Relocation

subjectgroup.subject: Allison WT Transmission Control Module Relocation

geninfo.para: This TSI applies to the 7600 and 8600 models with Caterpillar C10/12 and Cummins ISM engines. Trucks that operate in certain vocations that subject the under cab/chassis area to excessive debris and ice control chemicals may require the relocation of the Transmission Control Module for better environmental protection. The following procedures are required to relocate the Allison Transmission Control Module from inside the right side frame rail to inside the cab on the cab rear sill. For I-6 procedures see TSI-05-13-02.

entry.para: Harness for Caterpillar C10/12 and Cummins ISM

warning.para: To avoid property damage, personal injury, or death, park the vehicle on a flat level surface, set the parking brake, turn the engine off, and chock the wheels.

Batteries expel explosive gases. Keep sparks, flames, burning cigarettes, or other ignition sources away at all times. Always wear safety glasses and a face shield when working near batteries to avoid property damage, personal injury, or death.

step1.para: Remove the positive and negative battery cable from the battery connectors.
Locate the Transmission Control Module mounted to the inside of the right side frame rail under the cab. See Figure 1.

figure.caption: Figure 2. Disconnect Harness from Control Module

step1.para: Disconnect the three connectors from the Transmission Control Module and unbolt the module mounting bracket from the frame rail.

Disconnect the other end of the harness that was disconnected from the control module in step 3. Make note of its position on the connector mounting bracket at the rear of the transmission shown in Figure 2.

Disconnect and remove the chassis harness from the mounting bracket at the rear of the transmission. Disconnect and note where the other harness breakouts are connected on the right side of the transmission; i.e., the Vehicle speed sensor, the Turbine Speed Sensor, and the Engine Speed Sensor. See Figure 2. The only remaining connector/ harness on the transmission bracket should be the transmission harness feeding the transmission.

To make hookup easier, remove the remaining connector from the transmission bracket and re-install it so it faces rearward in the top mounting hole as shown in Figure 3. On some combinations this connector may already face rearward.

Position the replacement harness on top of the transmission. Route the engine compartment connectors into the engine compartment, the transmission end to the transmission mounted bracket at the rear of the transmission, and the Transmission Control Module end near the plugged hole in the center of the cab floor.
At the transmission end, connect the new harness connector to the relocated mating connector that goes into the transmission as shown in Figure 3.
Connect the speed sensor leads to the various speed sensors that were disconnected in Step 5.

Remove the rubber plug in the center of the cab floor and feed the transmission control module connectors through the floor. Along with the module connectors, make certain that the J1939 resistor and connector are also brought into the cab. See Figure 4.

note.para: In some applications the predrilled hole may be used by other body builder equipment. If necessary drill an additional 2 1/4" hole in the shifter filler panel near the existing hole and use rubber grommet to seal the cable and hole.

figure.caption: Figure 4. Connect New Harness Module Connectors and J1939 Resistor in Cab

step1.para: As you remove the old harness from above the transmission, route the new harness leading forward into the engine compartment into the same clipping points as the old.
Figure 5 illustrates the connectors that are now located in the engine compartment which must be connected in place of the old harness that can also be seen in the figure.

Disconnect the old harness and replace with the connectors supplied on the new harness. The single connector with the green wire will not be used and should be taped back against the harness. There may also be one or two body builder connectors that will not be used depending on the application of the truck being worked on.

The Transmission Control Module and mounting bracket will be relocated to the rear sill of the cab near the centerline of the cab. See Figure 6 for proper orientation of the bracket/module as it mounts to the floor. Location may vary depending on other equipment located in cab by the body builder.

Remove the module from the bracket. The flange of the bracket to be mounted to the floor will have one of the mounting holes already drilled. Locate another hole on the opposite end of the flange approximately ¾" in from both edges. Drill a ¼" hole.
Using the mounting bracket as a template, locate the two holes to be drilled through the cab floor sill. Drill two holes appropriate for mounting 3/16" self tapping bolts.
Mount the bracket using the newly drilled holes (Figure 6).

Connect the three connectors to the transmission control module. Connect black connector to "Black", the blue connector to "Blue", and the clear connector to "Gray". In addition to being color coded all connectors are keyed to the proper module connector. Don't force the connectors onto the wrong connector.
Remount the module to the bracket using the original hardware.
Fit the floor grommet to the cable and re-insert the grommet into the floor.

Make certain that the main harness from the transmission to the engine compartment is properly routed and clipped in the same fashion as the original, particularly those areas where the connections are made under the hood.
Reconnect battery cables and test for proper operation.
